testingProcedures.description:
Examine a sample of VPN configuration files to verify that the following requirements, at a minimum, are met:

  • Encapsulating Security Payload (ESP) is used to provide data confidentiality and authentication.

Document the design, development, and maintenance processes.

testingProcedures.description: Examine documentation of design, development, and maintenance processes to verify existence.

controls.control: Ensure these activities are based on industry standards and security is an integral part of the software life cycle process. Web applications must be developed based on secure coding guidelines such as: the OWASP Guide, SANS CWE Top 25, and CERT Secure Coding.

testingProcedures.description:
Examine policies and procedures to verify that:

  • The software life cycle process aligns with industry standards; and

  • Web application development is based on recognized secure coding guidelines.

controls.control: Document all software components for each system and describe the functionality provided.

testingProcedures.description: Examine documentation to verify it covers software components for each system and describes how they function.

controls.control: Protect any software backup copies from accidental destruction.

testingProcedures.description: Examine a sample of backups to verify they are adequately protected from accidental destruction.

controls.control: Design
The vendor must document the flow of personalization data within the environment from the receipt/generation to end of lifecycle.

testingProcedures.description: Interview personnel to verify documentation includes information to support the receipt/generation of data to the end of the lifecycle.
Examine data-flow diagrams for personalization data within the environment from the receipt/generation to end of lifecycle.

controls.control: Development
Ensure access to source code for applications used on the personalization network is restricted to authorized personnel only.

testingProcedures.description: Interview personnel to identify locations of application source code.
Examine system configuration and access control lists to identify users and processes that have access to source code components.
Examine approval records to ensure access to source code was authorized.

controls.control: Ensure that in-house developed personalization software logs any restart (and details associated with that restart event).

testingProcedures.description: Examine a sample of personalization logs to verify restart actions (and details associated with that restart event) are captured.
Examine log configuration settings to verify restart actions are included.
Interview personnel to identify in-house developed personalization logs.

controls.control: Ensure that in-house developed personalization software enforces authorization at restart.

testingProcedures.description: Examine restart procedures to ensure in-house developed personalization software enforces authorization at restart.

controls.control: Ensure separation of duties exists between the staff assigned to the development environment and those assigned to the production environment.

testingProcedures.description: Examine access-control settings to verify that access controls are in place to enforce separation personnel assigned to the development/test environments and the production environment(s).
Examine policies and procedures to verify a separation of duties between personnel assigned to the development/test environments and those assigned to the production environment.

controls.control: Ensure that software source code is restricted to only authorized staff. Staff access of source code must follow a documented process. The authorizations and approvals must be documented.

testingProcedures.description: Examine system configuration and access-control lists to identify users and processes that have access to source code components.
Examine documented policies and procedures for granting access to source code and verify authorizations and approvals are required.
Examine a sample of access request records to verify the access followed the documented process and was authorized.

controls.control: Use of Web Services for Issuer Interfaces

Mutual authentication is required. It must be implemented using either client and server X.509 certificates issued and signed by a trusted Certificate Authority (CA) or a VPN constructed in accordance with Section 4.6.2, “Virtual Private Network.”

testingProcedures.description: Examine system configurations and settings to ensure X.509 certificates, signed by a trusted Certificate Authority (CA) or VPN, are used.
Examine documentation for web services for issuer interfaces to identify mutual authentication is used.
If VPN is used, examine the VPN configuration and settings to ensure they adhere to requirements in Section 4.6.2.

controls.control:
The most current approved version of TLS is used to secure the connection and requires the following minimum cryptography standards. Refer to the Normative Annex A section of this document for acceptable algorithms and key strengths.

  • The strongest encryption reasonable must be implemented for the application if both client and server support higher than these minimum standards.

  • Implementations must disallow cipher renegotiation within an established TLS session.

  • Integrity protection must be provided through the use of the SHA-2 or higher algorithm.

testingProcedures.description:
Examine system configuration settings to verify:

  • Strong cryptography is used for the application.

  • Implementations disallow cipher renegotiation within an established TLS session.

  • Integrity protection is provided through the use of the SHA-2 or higher algorithm.

controls.control: All web services client and servers that are exposed to untrusted networks are protected by a suitably configured application firewall supporting message validation.

testingProcedures.description: Examine network system configurations and review applicable firewall rule sets to verify traffic is restricted and message validation is required.
Examine network diagrams and settings to identify interfaces where web services are exposed to untrusted networks—e.g., Internet.

controls.control: Implement controls to ensure message integrity.

testingProcedures.description: Examine network documentation to identify controls to support message integrity.
Examine network system configurations and review applicable firewall rule sets to verify message integrity is ensured.

controls.control: Software Implementation
Establish and maintain a documented software release process. Quality assurance must include testing of the code for security issues prior to any software releases.

testingProcedures.description: Examine documentation to verify a quality assurance process is required as part of the software release process and testing of code is performed before software is released.
Examine a sample of recent software updates and identify evidence to verify testing of the code was performed.
Interview personnel to verify a software release process exists and is in use.

controls.control: For internally developed software, ensure that security testing includes verification that temporary code, hard-coded keys, and suspicious code are removed.

testingProcedures.description: Examine documentation to verify it addresses removing temporary code, hard-coded keys, and suspicious code.
Examine a sample of recent internally developed software updates and verify steps to remove temporary code, hard-coded keys, and suspicious code were performed.
Examine policies/procedures to identify testing processes for internally developed software.

controls.control: Ensure all software implementation complies with Section 5.2, “Change Management.”

testingProcedures.description: Examine a sample of recent software updates to verify they comply with Section 5.2, “Change Management.”

controls.control: Test software prior to implementation to ensure correct operation.

testingProcedures.description: Examine a sample of recent software updates and verify evidence exists that testing software prior to implementation was performed.

controls.control: Prevent debugging within production environment.

testingProcedures.description: Examine policies/procedures to verify they address prevention of debugging within production environment.
Interview personnel to identify the controls in place to prevent debugging in the production environment.

controls.control: Have a predefined PC device configuration for PC devices used within the HSA.

testingProcedures.description: Examine a sample of PC devices used in the HSA and obtain evidence that the devices have been configured according to specified configuration standards.
Examine configuration standards for PC devices used within the HSA.

controls.control: Implement an approval process for all software beyond the standard PC device configuration for PC devices used within the HSA.

testingProcedures.description: Examine a sample of recent software updates and verify approvals were required.
Examine polices/procedures to identify the approval process for software used within the HSA.

controls.control: Ensure no unauthorized software can be installed.

testingProcedures.description: Examine the implementation of applicable controls to verify they are in place and in use.
Interview personnel to identify controls established to prevent unauthorized software from being installed.

controls.control: Ensure all software is transferred from development to production in accordance with the change-control process.

testingProcedures.description: Examine policies/procedures to identify change-control processes for software, including the methods used to transfer software from development to production.
Examine a sample of recent software updates and verify steps to transfer software from development to production were performed.

controls.control: User Management and System Access Control
User Management
Ensure that procedures are documented and followed by security personnel responsible for granting access to vendor’s networks, applications, and information.

testingProcedures.description: Examine a sample of recent access requests to verify they were processed by authorized personnel and in accordance with documented procedures.
Interview personnel to identify both those authorized to perform, and the processes followed for granting access to vendor’s network, applications, and information.
Examine documented procedures to ensure they address granting access to vendor’s networks, applications, and information.

controls.control: Restrict approval and level of access to staff with a documented business need before access is granted.

testingProcedures.description:
Examine policies/procedures to ensure they address that:

  • Approval and level of access must be restricted to those with a documented business need before access is granted; and

  • Documented approvals of access in place must be retained while the account is active.

controls.control: Retain documented approvals while the account is active, at a minimum.

testingProcedures.description:
Examine a sample of access requests to verify:

  • Users obtained associated approvals, and

  • Approval documentation has been retained for all active accounts.

controls.control: Restrict systems access by unique user ID to only those individuals who have a business need.

testingProcedures.description: Examine a sample of user accounts to verify each individual associated with a unique user ID has a documented, valid business need for the system access.

controls.control: Incorporate multi-factor authentication for all non-console access into HSA systems for personnel with administrative access.

testingProcedures.description: Interview personnel to verify that multi-factor authentication is used for all non-console access into HSA systems for personnel with administrative access.

controls.control: Incorporate multi-factor authentication for all remote network access (both user and administrator and including third-party access for support or maintenance) originating from outside the entity’s network.

testingProcedures.description: Examine a sample of remote network access system documentation and configuration settings to verify multi-factor authentication is used for remote network access connections.
Observe a sample of remote network access processes to verify multi-factor authentication is used.

controls.control: Only grant individuals the minimum level of access sufficient to perform their duties.

testingProcedures.description: Examine a sample of recent access requests to verify user access is limited to least privilege and based on documented business need.
Examine policies/procedures to verify they require that access be granted based on least-privilege principles sufficient to perform their duties.
Interview security administration personnel to verify access is granted based on least-privilege principles sufficient to perform their duties.

controls.control: Make certain that systems authentication requires at least the use of a unique ID and password.

testingProcedures.description: Examine system authentication settings and verify that user IDs in the system are unique and in order to gain access, a password is required.
Examine policies/procedures for system access to verify they require at least the use of a unique ID and password.

controls.control: Restrict administrative access to the minimum number of individuals required for management of the system.

testingProcedures.description: Interview management to understand the minimum number of administrative user resources required to support the personalization environment.
Examine user ID lists and security privileges to identify users with administrative access and verify the number of users with administrative aligns with management’s expectations.

controls.control: Ensure that group, shared, and generic accounts and passwords are disabled wherever the system supports unique values.

testingProcedures.description: Examine a sample of system components and user ID lists to verify group, shared, and generic accounts and passwords are disabled.
Examine polices/procedures to verify they require that group, shared, and generic accounts and passwords are disabled wherever the system supports unique values.

controls.control: Ensure that where generic administrative accounts cannot be disabled, these accounts are used only when unique administrator sign-on credentials are not possible and only in an emergency.

testingProcedures.description: Examine system security event log to identify when applicable generic administrative accounts were used and verify there is supporting documentation that authorizes their use in an emergency.
Interview system administration personnel to identify existence of generic accounts and how their usage is controlled.

Examine policies/procedures for the management of generic administrative accounts that cannot be disabled. Verify these accounts are used only when unique administrator sign-on credentials are not possible and only in an emergency.

controls.control: Ensure that when generic administrative accounts are used, the password is managed under dual control where no individual has access to the full password. Each component of the password must comply with the password control requirements in Section 6.2 below except for password length when an exception condition exists.

testingProcedures.description: Examine policies/procedures for the management of generic administrative account passwords and verify procedures require that such passwords be managed under dual control and in accordance with Section 6.2.
Interview system administration personnel to verify password-management practices require that generic administrative passwords are managed under dual control and in accordance with Section 6.2

controls.control: Validate all system access at least quarterly.

testingProcedures.description: Examine validation evidence to verify the activity is performed.
Interview personnel to verify system access is re-validated at least quarterly.

controls.control: Revalidate card production staff access to any systems upon a change of duties.

testingProcedures.description: Interview personnel to verify card production staff access is revalidated when the employee has a change in duties.
Examine a sample of HR transfer records and verify that revalidation was performed.

controls.control: Ensure that access controls enforce segregation of duties.

testingProcedures.description: Interview personnel to identify that policies/procedures support segregation of duties. See glossary definition, “Segregation of Duties,” in the Security Requirements.

controls.control: For cloud-based provisioning, restrict issuer access and privileges to only the issuer’s own cardholder data.

testingProcedures.description: Examine access-control settings to ensure access conforms to stated policies.
Interview personnel and identify controls that restrict issuer access and privileges to only the issuer’s own cardholder data.

controls.control: Strictly limit privileged or administrative access and ensure such access is approved by both the user’s manager and the IT Security Manager.

testingProcedures.description: Interview personnel to identify controls that limit privileged or administrative access.
Examine a sample of administrative-access requests and verify access was approved by the user’s manager and IT Security Manager.
Examine access-control settings to ensure access confirms to stated policies.

controls.control: Establish management oversight of privileged access to ensure compliance with segregation of duties.

testingProcedures.description: Examine evidence—e.g., audit logs—to verify management oversight is performed.
Interview personnel to identify controls that provide oversight of privileged access and compliance with segregation of duties policies.
Examine policies/procedures to verify they require oversight of privileged access that ensures compliance with segregation of duties.

controls.control: Ensure that all privileged administrative access is logged and reviewed weekly.

testingProcedures.description: Examine policies/procedures to verify that they require weekly review of privileged administrative access.
Examine evidence—e.g., access logs—to verify reviews are performed according to policies and procedures.

controls.control: Password Control
General
Implement a policy and detailed procedures relating to the generation, use, renewal, and distribution of passwords.

testingProcedures.description: Examine policy and detailed procedures to identify processes for generation, use, renewal, and distribution of passwords.

controls.control: Implement procedures for handling lost, forgotten, and compromised passwords.

testingProcedures.description: Interview system administrators to validate adherence to procedures.
Examine policy and detailed procedures to identify processes for handling lost, forgotten, and compromised passwords.

controls.control: Distribute password procedures and policies to all users who have access to cardholder data, or any system used as part of the personalization process.

testingProcedures.description: Examine procedures for disseminating password procedures and policies to users with access to cardholder data or any system used as part of the personalization process.
Interview a sample of user population to verify password procedures and policies were distributed.

controls.control: Ensure that only users with administrative privileges can administer other users’ passwords.

testingProcedures.description: Examine procedures for managing user IDs and verify that only users with administrative privileges can administer user passwords.
Observe a sample of user password resets and verify only users with administrative privileges can perform a reset.

controls.control: Not store passwords in clear text.

testingProcedures.description: Examine a sample of system components and their password files to verify that passwords are unreadable during storage.
Examine system documentation and configuration settings to verify that passwords are not stored in clear text.

controls.control: Change all default passwords.

testingProcedures.description: Examine a sample of system components and attempt to log on (with system administrator help) to the devices and applications using default vendor-supplied accounts and passwords. Verify that ALL default passwords have been changed. (Use vendor manuals and sources on the Internet to find vendor-supplied accounts/passwords.)

controls.control: Characteristics and Usage
Systems are configured so that newly issued and reset passwords are set to a unique value for each user.

testingProcedures.description: Interview personnel to verify newly issued and reset passwords are set to a unique value for each user.
Examine a sample of system configuration settings to verify newly issued and reset passwords are set to a unique value for each user.

controls.control: Newly issued passwords are changed on first use.

testingProcedures.description: Examine system configuration settings to verify newly issued passwords are changed on first use.

controls.control: “First use” passwords expire if not used within 24 hours of distribution.

testingProcedures.description: Examine system configuration settings to verify that first-time passwords are set to expire if not used within 24 hours.

controls.control: Systems enforce password lengths of at least 12 characters, with an exception for operating systems that do not support 12 characters. Passwords can never be less than a minimum length of 8 characters or an equivalent strength.

testingProcedures.description: Examine the system configuration settings for a sample of system components to verify that password parameters are set to require a minimum length of at least 12 characters or meet the exception condition.

controls.control:
Passwords consist of using a combination of at least three of the following categories:

  • Upper-case letters

  • Lower-case letters

  • Numbers

  • Special characters

testingProcedures.description:
Examine the system configuration settings for a sample of system components to verify that user passwords are set to require at least three of the following categories:

  • Upper-case letters

  • Lower-case letters

  • Numbers

  • Special characters

controls.control: Passwords are not the same as the user ID.

testingProcedures.description: Examine the system configuration settings for a sample of system components to verify passwords cannot be the same as the user ID.

controls.control: Passwords are not displayed during entry.

testingProcedures.description: Observe authentication procedures for entering a password and verify the password is not displayed as it is entered.

controls.control: Passwords are encrypted during transmission and rendered unreadable when stored.

testingProcedures.description: Examine a sample of passwords in transit and in storage to verify password values are not in clear text.
Examine password configurations to verify passwords are encrypted during transmission and rendered unreadable when stored.

controls.control: Passwords have a maximum life not to exceed 90 days and a minimum life of at least one day.

testingProcedures.description: Examine the system configuration settings for a sample of system components to verify that user password parameters are set to have a maximum life of not more than 90 days and a minimum life of at least one day.

controls.control: When updating passwords, the system prevents users from using a password that is the same as one of their previous four passwords.

testingProcedures.description: Examine the system configuration settings for a sample of system components to verify that password parameters are set to require that new passwords cannot be the same as the four previously used passwords.

controls.control: The user’s identity is verified prior to resetting a user password.

testingProcedures.description: Interview system administration personnel to verify the user’s identity is verified prior to resetting a user password.
Examine password reset procedures to verify the user’s identify is verified prior to resetting a user password.
Observe a password reset request to verify user identify is verified.

controls.control: Authentication credentials to the tokenization process are secured to prevent unauthorized disclosure and use.

testingProcedures.description: Interview personnel and review policies/procedures to identify controls that protect authentication credential to the tokenization process.

controls.control: Session Locking
Enforce the locking of an inactive session within a maximum of 15 minutes. If the system does not permit session locking, the user must be logged off after the period of inactivity.

testingProcedures.description: Observe a user session to verify the user is logged out after 15 minutes if the system does not permit session locking.
Examine the system configuration settings for a sample of system components to verify that system/session inactivity time out has been set to 15 minutes or less.

controls.control: Enforce a manual log-out process where manufacture and personalization equipment does not have the ability to automatically log off a user.

testingProcedures.description: Interview personnel to verify a manual log-out process is defined and in use when mechanisms do not exist to automatically log off a user.

controls.control: Account Locking
Accounts that have been inactive for a specified period (with a maximum of 90 days) must be removed from the system.

testingProcedures.description: Examine user accounts to verify that any inactive accounts over 90 days old are either removed or disabled.

controls.control: Systems must enforce the locking of a user account after a maximum of six unsuccessful authentication attempts.

testingProcedures.description: Examine the system configuration settings for a sample of system components to verify that authentication parameters are set to require that user accounts be locked out after not more than six invalid logon attempts.

controls.control: Locked accounts must only be unlocked by the security administrator. Alternatively, user accounts may be unlocked via automated password reset mechanisms. Challenge questions with answers that only the individual user would know must be used. These questions must be designed such that the answers are not information that is available elsewhere in the organization, such as in the Human Resources Department.

testingProcedures.description: Examine documented procedures to verify that accounts can only be unlocked by either the security administrator or other authorized individual, or via an automated password reset mechanism.
Examine polices/procedures for automated password reset mechanisms to verify they require conformance to the stipulated criteria.
Interview administrators to verify that an account is unlocked only after the identity of the user is verified.

Observe the mechanism including the challenge/response criteria, for accounts that can be unlocked via an automated reset mechanism, to verify the questions are designed as stipulated in the requirement.

controls.control: A user’s account must be locked immediately upon that user leaving the vendor’s employment until it is removed.

testingProcedures.description: Examine policies/procedures to verify that user access is locked when the user leaves the vendor’s employment.
Examine a record sample of users leaving vendor employment to verify that their account(s) were locked immediately.

controls.control: A user’s account must be locked immediately if that user’s password is known or suspected of being compromised.

testingProcedures.description: Examine policies/procedures to verify that any user account is immediately locked if the password is known or suspected of being compromised.

controls.control:
The user account logs including but not limited to the following must be reviewed at least twice each month for suspect lock-out activity:

  • Remote access

  • Database

  • Application

  • OS

testingProcedures.description: Examine documented procedures to verify access logs are reviewed at least weekly to identify suspicious activity.
Examine the system configuration settings and audit logs for a sample of system components to verify that lock-out activity is logged.

controls.control: Key Management: Secret Data
General Principles
A written description of the vendor’s cryptographic architecture must exist. In particular, it must detail all the keys used by each HSM. The key description must describe the key usage.

testingProcedures.description: Examine the written description of the vendor’s cryptographic architecture to verify that it includes details of all keys used by each HSM and a description of usage for each key.

controls.control: The principles of split knowledge and dual control must be included in all key life cycle activities involving key components to ensure protection of keys. The only exceptions to these principles involve those keys that are managed as cryptograms or stored within an SCD.

testingProcedures.description: Examine polices/procedures for key management to verify that they require the implementation of dual control and split knowledge for cryptographic key management.

controls.control: Effective implementation of these principles must enforce the existence of barriers beyond procedural controls to prevent any one individual from gaining access to key components or shares sufficient to form the actual key.

testingProcedures.description: Interview personnel to identify that controls exist beyond procedural controls to prevent any one individual from gaining access to key components or shares sufficient to form the actual key.
Examine a sample of evidence to verify controls are in place and functioning to prevent any one individual from gaining access to key components or shares sufficient to form the actual key.

controls.control: Where clear key components or shares pass through a PC or other equipment, the equipment must never be connected to any network and must be powered down when not in use. These computers must be dedicated and be hardened and managed under dual control at all times.

testingProcedures.description:
Examine documented procedures for all key-handling methods to verify that where clear key components or shares pass through a PC or other equipment, the equipment is:

  • Powered off when not in use;

  • Not connected to any network;

  • Dedicated and hardened; and

  • Managed under dual control at all times.

controls.control: Keys used for protection of keying material or other sensitive data must meet the minimums delineated in Annex A.

testingProcedures.description: Examine documentation—e.g., cryptography architecture—to identify keys used for the protection of keying material and other sensitive data and to verify the keys adhere to the minimums delineated in Annex A.

controls.control: All key-encrypting keys used to transmit or convey other cryptographic keys must be at least as strong as the key being transmitted or conveyed.

testingProcedures.description: Interview personnel to identify key-encrypting keys used to transmit or convey other cryptographic keys.
Examine documentation to verify identified keys are at least as strong as the keys being transmitted or conveyed.

controls.control: Cryptographic keys must not be hard-coded into software.

testingProcedures.description: Examine the software configuration—for example, shell scripts, command files, communication scripts, software code etc.—for a sample of system components to verify that cryptographic keys are not embedded.
Interview personnel to verify that the embedding of cryptographic keys into software—for example, in shell scripts, command files, communication scripts, software code etc.—is strictly prohibited.

controls.control: Audit trails must be maintained for all key-management activities.

testingProcedures.description: Examine a sample of key-management audit trails to verify existence.
Examine policies and procedures to verify that all key-management activities and all activities involving clear-text key components must be logged.

controls.control: Key-management activities must be performed by vendor or issuer staff.

testingProcedures.description: Examine documented key-management policies and procedures verify that all functions are performed by vendor or issuer staff.
Interview responsible personnel to verify that all functions are performed by vendor or issuer staff.

controls.control: Key-management activities must only be performed by fully trained and authorized personnel.

testingProcedures.description: Examine documented procedures and processes to verify that only authorized personnel have the ability to perform key-management activities.
Interview responsible personnel to ensure they have undergone relevant training for the key-management functions they perform.

controls.control: Digital certificates used in conjunction with cloud-based provisioning products or services must be issued either from a trusted Certificate Authority (CA) or directly under an issuer or application provider PKI.

testingProcedures.description: Interview personnel to verify the certificates have been issued either from a trusted Certificate Authority (CA) or directly under an issuer or application provider PKI.
Examine documentation to identify digital certificates used in conjunction with cloud-based provisioning products or services.

controls.control:
All key-management activities must be documented, and all activities involving clear key components must be logged. The log must include:

  • Unique identification of the individual that performed each function

  • Date and time

  • Function

  • Purpose

testingProcedures.description:
Examine a sample of audit logs and other documentation to verify that key-management activities are documented and activities involving clear-text key components are logged, and that the logs include:

  • Unique identification of the individual that performed each function

  • Date and time

  • Function performed

  • Purpose

Interview personnel to verify that key-management activities are documented and activities involving clear-text key components are logged, and the logs include:

  • Unique identification of the individual that performed each function

  • Date and time

  • Function performed

  • Purpose

controls.control: Symmetric Keys

Symmetric keys only exist in the following forms:

  • As plaintext inside the protected memory of a secure cryptographic device

  • As a cryptogram

  • As two or more full-length components (where each component must be the same length as the final key) or as part of an “m of n” sharing scheme where the value of “m” is at least 2.

testingProcedures.description:
Examine documented procedures and system configurations to verify symmetric keys exist only in the following forms:

  • As plaintext inside the protected memory of a secure cryptographic device

  • As a cryptogram

  • As two or more full-length components (where each component must be the same length as the final key) or as part of an “m of n” sharing scheme where the value of “m” is at least 2.

controls.control: Key components for each specific custodian must be stored in a separate, secure container that is accessible only by the custodian and/or designated backup(s).

testingProcedures.description: Examine a sample of key components and verify for each specific custodian that the keys are stored in a separate, secure container that is only accessible by the custodian and/or designated backup(s). This should include verification of access to physical keys, override keys, and/or PIN codes to access the containers.

controls.control: No single person shall be able to access or use all components or a quorum of shares of a single secret cryptographic key.

testingProcedures.description: Examine a sample of key components and verify no single person has access to or can use all components or have access to a quorum of shares of a single secret cryptographic key.

controls.control: Asymmetric Keys

Private keys exist only in the following forms:

  • As plaintext inside the protected memory of a secure cryptographic device

  • As a cryptogram

  • As two or more components or as part of an “m of n” sharing scheme where the value of “m” is at least 2; managed using the principles of dual control and split knowledge

testingProcedures.description:
Examine documented procedures to verify private keys exist only in the following forms:

  • As plaintext inside the protected memory of a secure cryptographic device

  • As a cryptogram

  • As part of an “m of n” sharing scheme where the value of “m” is at least 2

controls.control: Key components for each specific custodian must be stored in a separate, secure container that is accessible only by the custodian and/or designated backup(s).

testingProcedures.description: Examine a sample of key components and verify for each specific custodian that key components are stored in a separate, secure container that is accessible only by the custodian and/or designated backup(s).

controls.control: No single person shall be able to access or use all components or a quorum of shares of a single private cryptographic key.

testingProcedures.description: Examine documented procedures to verify that a single person cannot access or use all components or a quorum of shares of a single private cryptographic key.
Interview responsible personnel to verify that the implemented method(s) ensure that no single person can access or use all components or a quorum of shares of a single private cryptographic key.

controls.control:
Public keys must have their authenticity and integrity ensured. In order to ensure authenticity and integrity, a public key must be encrypted, or if in plaintext form, must exist only in one of the following forms:

  • Within a certificate,

  • Within a PKCS#10,

  • Within a SCD, or

  • With a MAC (message authentication code) created using the algorithm defined in ISO 16609.

testingProcedures.description: Interview responsible personnel to verify that the implemented method(s) ensure the authenticity and integrity of public keys.

Examine documented procedures for public keys to verify that public keys must exist only in one of the following forms:

  • Within a certificate,

  • Within a PKCS#10,

  • Within an SCD, or

  • With an associated MAC (message authentication code) created using the algorithm defined in ISO 16609.

controls.control:
Asymmetric keys also adhere to:

  • The payment system requirements for obtaining the issuer certificate

  • The payment system specification for asymmetric keys

testingProcedures.description: Examine documentation to identify requirements for obtaining an issuer certificate and the associated payment system(s) specifications.
Examine for a sample of asymmetric keys evidence to verify requirements were met.

controls.control: Key-Management Security Administration
controls.description: The secure administration of all key-management activity plays an important role in terms of logical security. The following requirements relate to the procedures and activities for managing keys and key sets.

controls.control: General Requirements
The vendor must define procedures for the transfer of key- management roles between individuals.

testingProcedures.description: Interview responsible personnel in applicable key-management roles to verify they are aware of and are following the documented procedures.
Examine documented procedures to verify that procedures for transferring key-management roles between individuals are defined.

controls.control: All physical equipment associated with key-management activity, such as physical keys, authentication codes, smart cards, and other device enablers—as well as equipment such as personal computers—must be managed following the principle of dual control.

testingProcedures.description: Observe the process of accessing physical equipment to verify that dual control is required to access or perform key-management functions.

Examine documented procedures to verify that access to physical equipment associated with key-management activity is managed such that no single person is able to access or perform key-management functions.

controls.control: Key Manager
There must be a nominated Key Manager with overall responsibility for all activities relating to key management.

testingProcedures.description: Examine documentation to verify the Key Manager has overall responsibility for all activities relating to key management.

controls.control: CISO must approve the Key Manager for the position within the vendor.

testingProcedures.description: Examine approval authorization documentation to verify CISO (or delegate) approved the Key Manager.

controls.control: The Key Manager must:
Have a nominated deputy.

testingProcedures.description: Examine documentation to identify the nominated deputy for the Key Manager.
Interview the Key Manager to verify that the Key Manager has a nominated deputy.

controls.control: Own and be responsible for ensuring that all key-management activity is fully documented.

testingProcedures.description: Examine documented policies and procedures for appropriateness.
Interview the Key Manager to verify that key-management activity is fully documented.

controls.control: Be responsible for ensuring that all key-management activity is carried out in accordance with the documented procedures.

testingProcedures.description: Interview the Key Manager to verify that all key-management activity is carried out in accordance with documented procedures.

controls.control: In collaboration with the personnel department, vet all key custodians to ensure their suitability for the role.

testingProcedures.description: Examine policies/procedures to identify vetting process for key custodians to ensure they are suitable for their role.
Examine documented evidence for a sample of key custodians that supports the vetting process.

controls.control: Be an employee of the vendor. This also applies to the deputy key manager.

testingProcedures.description: Examine employee rosters for the organization and verify that key custodians and the deputy key manager are employees of the vendor.

controls.control: The Key Manager must be informed immediately of any security breach or loss of integrity relating to key activities.

testingProcedures.description: Examine policies/procedures to identify process for reporting security breaches or other incidents associated with key activities to ensure the Key Manager is included in the process.

controls.control: The Key Manager must be responsible for ensuring that:
All key custodians have been trained with regard to their responsibilities, including incremental changes, and this forms part of their annual security training.

testingProcedures.description: Examine policies/ procedures to verify the requirement for annual security training for key custodians and that it includes key-custodian responsibilities.
Examine evidence for a sample of key custodians that verifies annual training is performed.

controls.control: Each custodian signs a statement, or is legally bonded, acknowledging that they understand their responsibilities.

testingProcedures.description: Examine a sample of key custodians’ signed statements acknowledging that they understand their responsibilities.

controls.control: Key custodians who form the necessary threshold to create a key must not report directly to the same manager. If the Key Manager is also a key custodian, other key custodians must not report to the Key Manager if, in conjunction with the Key Manager, that would form a threshold to create a key.

testingProcedures.description: Interview key custodians to verify that key custodians do not report to the Key Manager if the Key Manager is also a key custodian—because that would form a threshold to create a key.
Interview key custodians to verify that they report to a different manager if the custodians together form a threshold to create a key.
Examine personnel organization charts to verify applicable key custodians report to different managers.

controls.control: The Key Manager must not have the right to override operations of the key custodians or perform activities for other key custodians.

testingProcedures.description: Interview responsible personnel to verify that Key Managers do not have the right to override operations of the key custodians or perform activities for other key custodians.

controls.control: Key Custodians
The roles and responsibilities of key custodians must be fully documented at a level sufficient to allow performance of required activities on a step-by-step basis.

testingProcedures.description: Interview key custodian personnel to verify the documented roles and responsibilities allow performance of required activities on a step-by-step basis.
Examine documentation to verify that roles and responsibilities of key custodians are fully documented at a level sufficient to allow performance of required activities on a step-by-step basis.

controls.control: The identity of individual custodians must be restricted on a need-to-know basis and may not be made available in generally available documentation.

testingProcedures.description: Interview personnel to verify that identification of key custodians is based on a need-to-know basis and not identified in general documentation.

controls.control: The suitability of personnel must be reviewed on an annual basis.

testingProcedures.description: Examine documentation to verify that primary and backup key custodians are reviewed annually for suitability to the role.

controls.control: The key custodians must be employees of the vendor and never temporary staff or consultants.

testingProcedures.description: Examine documentation to verify that key custodians and their backups are employees of the vendor.
Interview a sample of key custodians to very they are employees of the vendor.

controls.control: They must be provided with a list of responsibilities and sign a statement acknowledging their responsibilities for safeguarding key components, shares, or other keying materials entrusted to them.

testingProcedures.description: Examine a sample of signed statements for key custodians to verify they acknowledge understanding of their responsibilities for safeguarding key components, shares, or other keying materials entrusted to them.
Interview responsible personnel to verify that key custodians are provided with a list of responsibilities for safeguarding key components, shares, or other keying materials entrusted to them.

controls.control: Only fully trained key custodians and their backups may participate in key-management activities.

testingProcedures.description: Examine policies/ procedures to verify that they require key custodians and their backups are fully trained in key-management activities.
Interview key custodians (and backups) to ensure training was required prior to performing key-management activities.

controls.control: Physical barriers must exist to ensure that no key custodian has access to sufficient components or shares to form the clear key.

testingProcedures.description: Observe physical barriers to ensure they are in place and active.
Interview personnel to identify the physical barriers that exist to ensure no key custodian has access to sufficient components or shares to form the clear key.

controls.control: Key-Management Device PINs
controls.description: In relation to PINs and pass-phrases used with key-management devices:

controls.control: If PINs or pass-phrases are stored, a copy of any PIN or pass- phrase, needed to access any device required for any key-management activity, must be stored securely (for recovery purposes).

testingProcedures.description: Interview personnel to identify secure storage requirements for PIN or pass-phrases.
Examine locations where the PIN or pass-phrase is stored and ensure it is stored securely.

controls.control: Only those individuals needing access to a device must have access to the PIN or pass-phrase for that device.

testingProcedures.description: Interview personnel to ensure that access to the PIN or pass-phrase is limited to only those person(s) needing access to the device.

controls.control: There must be a defined policy regarding the PINs and pass- phrases needed to access key-management devices. This policy must include the length and character-mix of such PINs and pass-phrases, and the frequency of change.

testingProcedures.description: Examine policy regarding using PINs and pass-phrases to access key-management devices to verify that the policy includes the length and character-mix of such PINs and pass-phrases, and the frequency of change.
Examine a sample of system settings to verify composition rules are enforced and the frequency of PIN/pass phrase change aligns with policy.

controls.control: All equipment associated with key-management activity, such as brass keys and smart cards, must not be in the control or possession of any one individual who could use those tokens to enable the key-management activity under single control. These tokens must be secured in a manner similar to key components, including the use of access-control logs for when removed or placed into secure storage.

testingProcedures.description: Interview personnel to identify controls to prevent key-management activity under single control.
Examine key-management activity audit logs to verify dual control was required for applicable activity.

controls.control: Key Generation
Asymmetric Keys Used for Payment Transactions
Adhere to the public-key algorithm and ensure that the length of issuer RSA key pairs used for payment-transaction processing is in accordance with payment-system requirements.

testingProcedures.description: Examine payment system requirements for public-key algorithms regarding the length of issuer key pairs and the vendor’s key-management documentation for consistency.

controls.control: Ensure that the generation of asymmetric key pairs ensures the secrecy of the private key and the integrity of the public key.

testingProcedures.description:
Examine key-management documentation and interview personnel to verify:

  • The generation of asymmetric key pairs ensures the secrecy of the private key and the integrity of the public key; and

  • Their creation and management are in compliance with the payment system requirements for obtaining the issuer certificate.

controls.control: Create and manage asymmetric keys in compliance with the payment system requirements for obtaining the issuer certificate.

testingProcedures.description: Examine payment system requirements for the creation and management of asymmetric keys and the vendor’s key-management documentation for consistency.

controls.control: Generate keys and key components using a random or pseudo- random process (as described in ISO 9564-1 and ISO 11568-5) that is capable of satisfying the statistical tests of National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) PUB 800-22.

testingProcedures.description: Examine key-management documentation including, where necessary, documentation of the secure cryptographic devices to verify that keys and key components are generated using a random or pseudo-random process described in ISO 9564-1 and ISO 11568-5 that is capable of satisfying the statistical tests of NIST SP 800-22 or equivalent.

controls.control: Key generation must take place in a hardware security module (HSM) that has achieved PCI approval or FIPS 140-2 or 140-3 Level 3 or higher certification for physical security.
controls.description: During operation, the HSM must utilize a security algorithm that complies with payment system requirements as defined in Annex A.

testingProcedures.description:
Interview personnel to verify that:

  • Key generation takes place in a secure cryptographic device—e.g., HSM.

  • The HSM has achieved PCI approval or FIPS 140-2 Level 3 or higher certification for physical security.

Examine key-management/device documentation to verify that:

  • Key generation takes place in a secure cryptographic device—e.g., HSM.

  • The HSM has achieved PCI approval or FIPS 140-2 Level 3 or higher certification for physical security.

  • During key-generation, the HSM utilizes a secure algorithm that complies with Annex A of this document.

controls.control: Cables must be inspected under dual control to ensure disclosure of a plaintext key or key component or share is not possible.

testingProcedures.description: Observe personnel performing inspection of cables to verify that procedures are followed.

Examine key-management documentation to verify that procedures are in place to inspect cables under dual control prior to key-management activity, to ensure disclosure of a clear-text key or key component is not possible.

controls.control: Use the principles of split knowledge and dual control during the generation of any cryptographic keys in component or share form.

testingProcedures.description: Interview personnel to verify that split knowledge and dual control are required during the generation of any cryptographic keys in component or share form.
Examine a sample of key-ceremony records and events to verify that split knowledge and dual control are required during the generation of any cryptographic keys in component or share form.

controls.control: Key components, if printed, must be created in such a way that the key component cannot be tapped or observed during the process by other than the authorized key custodian. Additionally, the key components cannot be observed on final documents without evidence of tampering.

testingProcedures.description:
Interview personnel to verify that any printed key components:

  • Are created in such a way that they cannot be observed in the creation process by anyone other than the authorized key custodian; and

  • Cannot be observed on final documents without evidence of tampering.

Examine procedures to verify that printed key components are created in such a way that the key component cannot be tapped or observed during the process by other than the authorized key custodian and cannot be observed on final documents without evidence of tampering.

controls.control: Immediately destroy any residue from the printing or generation process that might disclose a component so that an unauthorized person cannot obtain it.

testingProcedures.description: Examine key-management documentation to verify that any residue from the printing or generation process is immediately destroyed.
Interview personnel to verify that procedures are followed.

controls.control: Ensure that a generated key is not at any time observable or otherwise accessible in plaintext to any person during the generation process.

testingProcedures.description: Observe a key-generation process (live or demonstration if necessary) to verify procedures are followed.
Interview personnel to verify that any generation of keys is not observable or otherwise accessible in clear text to any other person during the generation process.

controls.control: Key components or shares must be placed in pre-serialized, tamper-evident envelopes when not in use by the authorized key custodian.

testingProcedures.description: Interview personnel to verify that key components or shares are placed in pre-serialized, tamper-evident envelopes when not in use by the authorized key custodian.
Examine locations of key components or shares not in use by the authorized key custodian to verify they are contained in pre-serialized, tamper-evident envelopes.

controls.control: Key Distribution
Keys must be distributed only in their allowable forms.

testingProcedures.description: Examine key-management documentation to verify that keys are distributed only in their allowable forms in accordance with Sections 7.2, “Symmetric Keys, and 7.3, “Asymmetric Keys.”

controls.control: When transmitted electronically, keys and key components or shares must be encrypted prior to transmission following all key-management requirements documented in this section.

testingProcedures.description: Examine key-management documentation to verify that keys and key components or shares are encrypted prior to electronic transmission.

controls.control: Ensure that private or secret key components or shares and keying data that are sent as plaintext meet the following requirements:

Use different communication channels such as different courier services. It is not sufficient to send key components or shares for a specific key on different days using the same communication channel.

testingProcedures.description: Examine documentation for conveying key components to verify that the use of different communication channels, such as different courier services and not the same courier on different days, is required.
Examine key-management activity audit logs to verify key components were sent according to required procedures.

controls.control: A two-part form that identifies the sender and the materials sent must accompany the keying data.

testingProcedures.description: Examine the two-part form to verify that it includes details of the sender and the material sent.
Examine procedures for key generation to ensure a two-part form is used and the form identifies the materials sent.

controls.control: The form must be signed by the sender and require that the recipient return one part of the form to the originator.

testingProcedures.description: Examine a sample of recently generated key components and verify the forms were adequately signed and returned according to procedures.

controls.control: Key components or shares must be placed in pre-serialized, tamper-evident envelopes for shipment.

testingProcedures.description: Examine policies/procedures to verify that key components or shares are placed in pre-serialized TEE bags prior to shipment.
Examine a sample of key-management activity logs and verify that pre-serialized numbers are logged as part of the process.

controls.control: Key components or shares must only be received by the authorized custodian, who must:

Inspect and ensure that no one has tampered with the shipping package. If there are any signs of tampering, the key must be regarded as compromised and the vendor’s key-compromise procedures document must be followed.

testingProcedures.description: Examine a sample of key-management activity logs and verify that pre-serialized numbers are logged as part of the process.
Interview personnel to verify that procedures are followed.

controls.control: Verify the contents of the package with the attached two-part form.

testingProcedures.description: Examine procedures for key-component receipt to verify a two-part form is used and the form identifies the materials sent.
Interview personnel to verify that procedures are followed.

controls.control: Return one part of the form to the sender of the component or share, acknowledging receipt.

testingProcedures.description: Interview personnel to verify that procedures are followed.
Examine procedures for key-component receipt to verify that one part of the form is returned to the sender of the component or share, acknowledging receipt.

controls.control: Securely store the component or share according to the vendor’s key-storage policy.

testingProcedures.description: Interview personnel to verify that procedures are followed.
Examine procedures for key-component receipt to verify that the component or share is securely stored according to the vendor’s key-storage policy.

controls.control: Before entities accept a certificate, they must ensure that they know its origin, and prearranged methods to validate the certificate status must exist and must be used. This includes the valid period of usage and revocation status, if available.

testingProcedures.description: Examine key-management documentation to verify that prior to certificate acceptance a prearranged method to validate certificate status is in place and includes the valid period of usage and revocation status, if available.
Interview personnel to verify that procedures are followed.

controls.control: Key Loading
controls.description: The following requirements relate to the loading of clear-text cryptographic key components/shares into HSMs.

controls.control: Any hardware used in the key-loading function must be dedicated, controlled, and maintained in a secure environment under dual control. Effective January 2018, all newly deployed key-loading devices must be SCDs, either PCI-approved or FIPS 140-2 or 140-3 Level 3 or higher certification for physical security.

testingProcedures.description: Observe any hardware used in the key-loading function to verify it is dedicated, controlled, and maintained in a secure environment and under dual control.
Examine key-management documentation to verify that any hardware used in the key-loading function is dedicated, controlled, and maintained in a secure environment under dual control.
Examine documentation to verify that all newly deployed key-loading devices are SCDs and are either PCI-approved or FIPS 140-2 or 140-3 Level 3 or higher certification for physical security.

controls.control: Prior to loading keys (or components/shares), the target cryptographic devices, cabling, and paper components must be inspected for any signs of tampering that might disclose the value of the transferred key (or components/shares).

testingProcedures.description: Examine key-management documentation to verify that the target cryptographic devices, cabling, and paper components are inspected for any signs of tampering prior to key loading.
Observe personnel performing physical inspections of the target cryptographic devices, cabling, and paper components to verify processes are followed to detect signs of tampering prior to key loading

controls.control: Tokens, PROMs, or other key component/share mechanisms used for loading keys (or key components/shares) must only be in the physical possession of the designated custodian (or their backup), and only for the minimum practical time.

testingProcedures.description:
Examine key-management documentation to verify that all key/key component/key share-holding mechanisms used for loading keys, key components, or shares are:

  • In the physical possession of the designated custodian or their backup, and

  • Only for the minimum practical time.

controls.control: In relation to key transfer devices:
Any device used to transfer keys between the cryptographic device that generated the key(s) and the cryptographic devices that will use those key(s), must itself be a secure cryptographic device.

testingProcedures.description: Examine vendor/device documentation to verify that a device used to transfer keys between the cryptographic device that generated the key(s) and the cryptographic devices that will use those key(s), is itself a secure cryptographic device.

controls.control: After loading a key or key components into the target device, the key transfer device must not retain any residual information that might disclose the value of the transferred keying material.

testingProcedures.description: Interview personnel to verify that residual information is not retained after key loading.
Observe a key-loading ceremony and verify information is not retained after transferring the keying material.

controls.control: All key-loading activities must be under the control of the Key Manager.

testingProcedures.description: Examine key-management documentation and interview personnel to verify that all key-loading activities are performed under the control of the Key Manager.
Observe key-loading activities to verify that all such activities are under control of the Key Manager.

controls.control: Control and maintain any tokens, electronically erasable programmable read-only memory (EEPROM), physical keys, or other key component/share-holding devices used in loading keys in a secure environment under dual control.

testingProcedures.description: Observe personnel performing key loading to verify that all key/key component/key share-holding mechanisms are handled under dual control.
Examine key-management documentation to verify that all key/key component/key share-holding device used for key loading are managed under dual control.

controls.control: Make certain that the key-loading process does not disclose any portion of a key component/share to an unauthorized individual.

testingProcedures.description: Examine key-management documentation to verify that the key-loading process does not disclose any portion of a key component/share to an unauthorized individual.
Interview personnel to verify that procedures are followed.

controls.control: If the key component/share is in human-readable form, ensure that it is only visible at one point in time to the key custodian and only for the duration of time required to load the key.

testingProcedures.description: Interview personnel to verify that procedures are followed.

Examine key-management documentation to verify that any key component/share that is human-readable is only visible:

  • At one point in time to the key custodian, and

  • For the duration of time required to load the key.

controls.control: In the loading of keys or key components/shares, incorporate a validation mechanism to ensure the authenticity of the keys and ascertain that they have not been tampered with, substituted, or compromised. If used for this purpose, check values for key and key components must not be the full length of the key or its components. Validation must be performed under dual control. The outcome of the process (success or otherwise) must be reported to the Key Manager.

testingProcedures.description:
Examine key-management documentation to verify that for all keys or key components/shares loaded:

  • A validation mechanism is in place to ensure authenticity of the keys and key components and provide assurance that the keys and key components have not been tampered with, substituted, or compromised;

  • If check values are used, they are not the full length of the key or key components/shares;

  • The validation process is performed under dual control; and

  • The outcome of the validation process is reported to the Key Manager.
Observe personnel performing validation processes to verify that they are conducted under dual control and the outcomes are reported to the Key Manager.

controls.control:
Once a key or its components/shares have been loaded and validated as operational, either:

  • Securely destroy or delete it from the key-loading materials as defined in Section 7.11, “Key Destruction”; or

  • Securely store it according to these requirements if preserving the keys or components/shares for future loading.

testingProcedures.description: Observe personnel performing process to verify that either secure destruction or deletion, or secure storage of the key and/or its components/shares is performed.

Examine key-management documentation to verify that once a key and/or its components/shares have been loaded and validated as operational, the key and/or its components/shares are either:

  • Securely destroyed or deleted from the key-loading materials, or

  • If the keys or its components/shares are to be used for future loading, they are securely stored in accordance with requirements in this document.

controls.control: During the key-loading process, key custodians as well as the key manager must verify that the key usage set for the key being loaded matches the keys intended use. This information must be recorded in an audit trail of the key ceremony.

testingProcedures.description: Examine key ceremony audit logs to ensure they are complete and correct.
Examine key-management documentation to verify procedures are in place to validate key usage.

controls.control: Key Storage
controls.description: The following requirements relate to the secure storage of secret keys, private keys, and their plaintext key components or shares.

controls.control: Key components/shares must be stored in pre-serialized, tamper- evident envelopes in separate, secure locations (such as safes).

testingProcedures.description: Observe storage locations to verify the envelopes are stored in separate, secure locations.

Examine key-management documentation and interview personnel to verify:

  • Key components/shares are stored in pre-serialized, tamper-evident envelopes;

  • The envelopes are stored in secure locations (such as safes); and

  • Removal of the envelopes from their secure location is detectable.
Observe the envelopes used to verify that they are pre-serialized and tamper-evident.

controls.control: These envelopes must not be removable without detection.

testingProcedures.description: Observe storage locations to verify the envelopes cannot be removed without detection.
Examine key-management documentation and interview personnel to verify removal of the envelopes from their secure location is detectable.

controls.control: An inventory of the contents of key storage safes must be maintained and audited quarterly.

testingProcedures.description:
Examine key-management documentation and interview personnel to verify that:

  • An inventory of the contents of key storage safes is maintained; and

  • The inventory is audited at least quarterly.
Examine inventory and audit documentation to verify inventory is complete and audits are performed at least quarterly.

controls.control: Where a secret or private key component/share is stored on a token—e.g., an integrated circuit card—and an access code—e.g., a personal identification number (PIN)) or similar access-control mechanism is used to access that token, only that token’s owner (or designated backup) must be allowed possession of both the token and its corresponding access code.

testingProcedures.description: Examine key-management documentation for secret or private key component/shares that are stored on a physical media to verify that the key custodian (or designated backup) is the only person allowed possession of both the media and its corresponding access code.

controls.control:
Ensure that access logs, at a minimum, include the following:

  • Date and time (in/out)

  • Names and signatures of the key custodians involved

  • Purpose of access

  • Serial number of envelope (in/out)

testingProcedures.description: Examine key-management documentation to verify that access logs are maintained.

Examine access logs to key component/share storage and verify that they contain:

  • Date and time (in/out)

  • Names and signatures of the key custodians involved

  • Purpose of access

  • Serial number of envelope (in/out)

controls.control: Keep the access and destruction logs for master keys until after cards using keys protected by those master keys are no longer in circulation.

testingProcedures.description: Examine key-management documentation to verify that logs for access and destruction of master keys are retained until at least after all keys protected by those master keys are retired and no longer in circulation.

controls.control: Key Usage
Each key must be used for only one purpose and not shared between payment systems, issuers, or cryptographic zones, for example:
Private keys shall be used only to create digital signatures OR to perform decryption operations. Private keys shall never be used to encrypt other keys.

testingProcedures.description: Examine documentation to identify controls that ensure private keys are used only to create digital signatures or perform decryption and that private keys shall not be used to encrypt other keys.
Examine evidence that verifies controls are in place and active.

controls.control: RSA signature (private) keys must be prohibited from being used for the encryption of either data or another key, and similarly RSA encryption (public) keys must be prohibited from being used to generate signatures.

testingProcedures.description: Examine documentation to identify controls that ensure private keys are used only to create digital signatures or perform decryption; that private keys shall not be used to encrypt other keys; and RSA encryption (public) keys must be prohibited from being used to generate signatures.
Examine evidence that verifies controls are in place and active.

controls.control: Public keys shall be used only to verify digital signature OR perform encryption operations.

testingProcedures.description: Examine documentation to identify controls that ensure public keys can only be used to verify digital signatures OR perform encryption operations.
Examine evidence that verifies controls are in place and active.

controls.control: Key-encrypting keys must never be used as working keys (session keys) and vice versa.

testingProcedures.description: Examine policies/procedures to identify controls that KEKs are not used as working keys and vice versa.
Examine evidence that verifies controls are in place and functioning.

controls.control: Key-encipherment keys used to encrypt other keys for conveyance—e.g., KEK, ZCMK—must be unique per established key zone and, optionally, unique per issuer within that zone. These keys must only be shared between the two communicating entities and must not be shared with any third organization.

testingProcedures.description:
Examine documentation to verify it requires that key-encipherment keys are:

  • Unique per established key zone

  • Only shared between the two communicating entities
Interview key custodians and key-management supervisory personnel to verify the implementation of the aforementioned.

controls.control: The HSM must enforce a separation of keys to prevent keys from being used for purposes other than those for which they were intended.

testingProcedures.description: Observe HSM settings and configurations to verify they enforce a separation of keys.
Examine key-management documentation to verify that cryptographic keys are only used for the one, specific purpose for which they were defined.

controls.control: All secret and private keys must have a predefined expiry date by which they must be retired from use. No key must be used for a period longer than the designated life span of that key. Issuer keys must not be used for longer than the issuer-specified expiry date.

testingProcedures.description:
Examine documented key-management policies and procedures to verify that they require that:

  • All secret and private keys have a predefined expiry date by which they must be retired from use and cannot be used for a period longer than the designated life span of that key.

  • Issuer-provided keys with a defined expiry date are not used after the issuer-specified expiry date.
Observe issuer keys currently in use to verify they are within the issuer-specified expiry date.

controls.control: There must be no process by which, once deployed, the life of a key can be extended beyond its original designated life span.

testingProcedures.description: Examine key-management procedures to ensure a key cannot be extended beyond its original designated life span after deployment.

controls.control: The vendor must:
Prohibit any keys from being shared or substituted between production and test systems.

testingProcedures.description: Observe a demonstration of the processes for generating and loading keys into test systems to verify they have no association with production keys.
Examine key-management documentation to verify that cryptographic keys are never shared or substituted between production and test/development systems.
Observe a demonstration of the processes for generating and loading keys into production systems to verify they have no association with test or development keys.

controls.control: Prohibit keys used for pilots (i.e., limited production—for example via time, capabilities, or volume) from being used for full product rollout unless the keys were managed to the same level of security compliance as required for production.

testingProcedures.description: Interview key custodians and key-management supervisory personnel to verify the implementation of the aforementioned.

Examine key-management documentation to verify that keys used for pilots are not used for full product rollout unless the keys were managed to the same level of security compliance as required for production.

controls.control: Ensure that any keys used for prototyping—i.e., using cards for proof of concept or process where production keys are not used—are not used in production.

testingProcedures.description: Interview key custodians and key-management supervisory personnel to verify the implementation of the aforementioned.
Examine key-management documentation to verify that keys used for prototyping are not used in production.

controls.control: Make certain that the life of keys used to encrypt other keys is shorter than the time required to conduct an exhaustive search of the key space. Only algorithms and key lengths stipulated in Normative Annex A of this document shall be allowed.

testingProcedures.description: Interview key custodians and key-management supervisory personnel to verify the implementation of the aforementioned.
Examine documented procedures to verify procedures require that only the algorithms and key lengths stipulated in Normative Annex A of this document be used.
Examine documented procedures to verify procedures require that the life of key-encrypting keys (KEKs) is shorter than the time required to conduct an exhaustive search of the key space.

controls.control: Ensure that private and secret keys exist in the minimum number of locations consistent with effective system operation.

testingProcedures.description: Examine documented procedures to verify that private and secret keys exist in the minimum number of locations consistent with effective system operation.
Interview key custodians and key-management supervisory personnel to verify the implementation of the aforementioned.

controls.control: Not use key variants except within the device with the original key.

testingProcedures.description: Interview key custodians and key-management supervisory personnel to verify the implementation of the aforementioned.

Examine documented procedures for generating all types of keys and verify the procedures ensure that only unique keys, or sets of keys, are used, and any key variants exist only within the device with the original key.

controls.control: Only use private keys to decipher or to create a digital signature; public keys must only be used to encipher or to verify a signature.

testingProcedures.description: Examine documented procedures to verify that private keys are only used to decipher or to create a digital signature; and public keys are only used to encipher or to verify a signature.

controls.control: Maintain an inventory of keys under its management to determine when a key is no longer required—e.g., could include key label/name, effective date, expiration date, key purpose/type, key length, etc.

testingProcedures.description:
Examine key inventory records to verify the following details are included:

  • Key label/name

  • Effective date
